description: Explore the fundamental principles of forces and motion through Ghanaian contexts. Learn kinematics, Newton's laws, and their applications in transportation and daily life.
creator: Ghana STEM Learning Platform

tasks.title: Introduction to Motion
tasks.description: Begin your journey into physics by understanding basic motion concepts and their importance in Ghanaian transportation and daily activities.

questions.question: What is the SI unit for distance?
questions.explanation: The SI unit for distance is the meter (m). This is used to measure how far objects travel.

questions.question: If a tro-tro (minibus) travels 50 kilometers in 2 hours, what is its average speed in km/h?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time = 50 km ÷ 2 hours = 25 km/h.

questions.question: Which of these represents velocity?
questions.explanation: Velocity includes both speed and direction. '25 km/h north' specifies both the speed and direction of motion.

hints: Remember the speed formula: speed = distance ÷ time
Velocity includes direction, speed does not
tasks.completionMessage: Excellent! You understand basic motion concepts. Now let's explore acceleration and kinematics.

tasks.title: Kinematics and Equations
tasks.description: Master the kinematic equations and learn to solve motion problems step by step.

questions.question: What is the SI unit for acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, so its unit is meters per second squared (m/s²).

questions.question: A car accelerates from rest to 20 m/s in 5 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Using a = (v - u)/t where v = 20 m/s, u = 0 m/s, t = 5 s: a = (20 - 0)/5 = 4 m/s².

questions.question: Which kinematic equation relates displacement, initial velocity, time, and acceleration?
questions.explanation: The equation s = ut + ½at² relates displacement (s), initial velocity (u), time (t), and acceleration (a).

hints: Use the appropriate equation for the given variables
tasks.completionMessage: Great! You're mastering kinematics. Let's move to Newton's laws of motion.

tasks.title: Newton's Laws of Motion
tasks.description: Understand the three fundamental laws that govern motion and their applications in everyday life.

questions.question: What is Newton's First Law also known as?
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law is also known as the Law of Inertia, which states that objects tend to maintain their state of motion unless acted upon by an external force.

questions.question: If a force of 50 N acts on a mass of 10 kg, what is the acceleration? (Use F = ma)
questions.explanation: Using F = ma: 50 = 10a, so a = 50/10 = 5 m/s².

questions.question: When you push a wall and the wall pushes back, this demonstrates:
questions.explanation: This demonstrates Newton's Third Law: for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

hints: Remember the three laws and their names
Use F = ma for force calculations
tasks.completionMessage: Excellent! You understand Newton's laws. Now let's apply them to Ghanaian scenarios.

tasks.title: Ghanaian Applications
tasks.description: Apply physics principles to real-world problems in Ghana, including transportation safety and agricultural machinery.

questions.question: A tro-tro driver needs to stop within 20 meters when traveling at 15 m/s. If the deceleration is constant, what is the minimum deceleration needed? (Use v² = u² + 2as)
questions.explanation: Using v² = u² + 2as where v = 0, u = 15 m/s, s = 20 m: 0 = 15² + 2a(20), so 0 = 225 + 40a. Therefore a = -225/40 = -5.625 m/s² (negative because it's deceleration).

questions.question: Why do seatbelts save lives in car accidents?
options: They make the car look safer
They reduce the force on passengers by increasing stopping time
questions.explanation: Seatbelts increase the stopping time, which reduces the force on passengers (F = ma, where a = change in velocity ÷ time).

hints: Use the kinematic equation v² = u² + 2as
Remember that deceleration is negative acceleration
Think about how seatbelts affect stopping time
tasks.completionMessage: Fantastic! You've applied physics to real Ghanaian transportation scenarios.

tasks.title: Final Challenge: Safety Engineer
tasks.description: Design safety solutions for Ghanaian transportation using your knowledge of forces and motion.

questions.question: A Ghanaian farmer wants to design a safe ramp for loading produce onto trucks. If the ramp is 5 meters long and the truck bed is 1.5 meters high, what is the angle of the ramp? (Use trigonometry: sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse)
questions.explanation: Using sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse = 1.5/5 = 0.3. Therefore θ = sin⁻¹(0.3) ≈ 17.46°.

questions.question: In the ramp problem, if the angle is too steep, what happens to the force needed to push objects up the ramp?
questions.explanation: As the angle increases, the component of weight parallel to the ramp increases, requiring more force to push objects up the ramp.

hints: Use the sine function: sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse
Find the inverse sine to get the angle
Think about how ramp angle affects the force needed
tasks.completionMessage: Congratulations! You've completed the Forces and Motion room and earned the 'Motion Master' badge!
